text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 5.16.1.1.2, Authority: added in new (2) TBOR content updated based on guidance from the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (National Taxpayer Advocate Program) and Branch 3 of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration). Added in new (3) IRC 6343(e) requires the release of a levy on salary or wages payable to or received by a taxpayer, upon agreement with the taxpayer that the tax is currently not collectible.
5.16.1.1.7, Related Resources:, updated citations and links to reference materials and created (2) to address the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR).
IRM 5.16.1.2, Currently Not Collectible Procedures: added a note under the chart to address closing codes for TC 530 cc 37, cc 38 and cc 39.

IRM 5.16.1.2.6(11), Defunct Corporations, Exempt Organizations, Limited Liability Partnerships, and Limited Liability Companies: moved guidance regarding no trust fund due cases to paragraph 12, which resulted in the renumbering of the following two paragraphs.
IRM 5.16.1.2.9(10), Hardship: clariﬁed language regarding the levy release to more closely follow the statute.
IRM 5.16.1.2.9(16), Hardship:, added a note providing the procedures to populate the fax number on Letter 4223 through ICS.
5.16.1.2.10(2), International: updated the number of MCAR countries from ﬁve to six.
5.16.1.3.5, Preparer, Promoter, Appraiser, Material Advisor and Aiding & Abetting Penalties: “Earned Income Tax Credit” with Return Preparer Visitation Coordinator.”
IRM 5.16.1.3.6(1), MFT 35 Shared Responsibility Payment (SRP) and MFT 65 Mirrored Shared Responsibility Payment: added last year SRP was assessed
Replaced the word “the Service” with “the IRS” throughout this IRM.

) This IRM provides procedures for determining when an account is currently collectible (CNC). These procedures are used by all functions when reporting and an account as uncollectible. (
) Purpose - This chapter provides the requirements for reporting accounts un- collectible, including the level of approval authority necessary for different types of CNC closures. (
) Audience - These procedures and guidance apply to IRS employees sible for reporting collection accounts as uncollectible, primarily IRS Field Collection revenue officers and group managers. (
) Policy Owner – The Director of Collection Policy is the policy owner of this IRM. Collection Policy is an organization under the Small Business/Self- Employed Division (SBSE), Collection. (
) Program Owner – SB/SE Collection Policy, Case Resolution Alternatives, is the program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders - The primary stakeholders affected or impacted by IRM are Field Collection, Specialty Collection Insolvency, Appeals and Taxpayer Advocate Service. (

) Program Goals - In certain circumstances, collection personnel may determine that an account is currently uncollectible. By following the proce- dures in this IRM, employees will be able to properly and accurately close collection accounts as currently not collectible. All IRS personnel are respon- sible for execution of duties in accordance with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights as listed in IRC

fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC

) Revenue officers should not close accounts as UTL or UTC if the taxpayer is known to have a current address outside the United States, and the revenue officer can conﬁrm an address or a country of residence for the taxpayer. For accounts having a current address outside the United States, follow proce- dures in IRM

, Account Transfers to International, to transfer the account to SB/SE International. For taxpayers known to be living outside the country, but with an unconﬁrmed address, request a courtesy investigation in accordance with IRM
, Originating Office Procedure. Taxpayers residing in U.S. possessions and territories (aka insular areas), are treated the same those residing in the United States. (

) Asset checks for UTL/UTC should generally be completed within one year of closing the case as CNC. ) Do not solicit voluntary payments on accounts barred by statute. If a makes a payment on an account barred by statute, inform them that is not required and ask if he/she still wishes to make the payment or have it returned. The taxpayer must be advised that the payment is purely voluntary and will be treated as a gift to the United States Treasury. If the taxpayer’s tentions cannot be ascertained, return the payment. (

) Because state law speciﬁes that the owner of an LLC has no direct in LLC assets, the property of the LLC is not available for collection action when the owner is identiﬁed as the liable taxpayer. Field Collection deﬁnes return preparer penalties as civil penalties with MFT 13 or MFT 55 that have the following penalty reference numbers (PRN): 606, 581, 624, 714, 715, 716, 717, 718, 626, 627, 628, 631, 633, 634, 636, 645, 648 or 650.

Return Preparer Coordinators (RPCs) and Return Preparer Visitation (RPV) coordinators play a critical role in the assessment process of return preparer penalties and can be a very valuable resource for revenue officers. For example:

Revenue officers may contact the RPC or RPV coordinator to determine if the Return Preparer Penalty case ﬁle is available. Revenue officers may contact the RPC or RPV coordinator to obtain a client list. This list may help provide leads for the collection investigation and can be used to corroborate a return preparer’s claim that he/she has ceased doing business as a return preparer. For example, by con
tacting the former clients of a return preparer who claims he/she has ceased doing business, the RO may ﬁnd out that the return preparer is

still preparing returns, but has changed the name of the business and is not signing the returns and/or is having others sign as the preparer (e.g., spouse, employee, etc.). Former clients may also prove valuable for obtaining asset information and levy sources.

Revenue officers should contact the designated coordinator in the RO’s area using the following links: Link for Return Preparer Coordinator: http://mysbse.web.irs.gov/ exam/tip/rp/contacts/12293.aspx. Link for Return Preparer Visitation Coordinator (RPV)https://program.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/SbEHqEpRpv2/_layouts/15/start.aspx#/Site-Pages/Home.aspx.

personally liable for partnership liabilities), and LLCs (where the owner is tiﬁed as the liable taxpayer) the TPI is determined by the annual income of individual, general partner or member. The Social Security Number (SSN) of the individual, general partner or member of an LLC (where the owner is tiﬁed as the liable taxpayer) must be cross-referenced on IDRS. These cases do not require a mandatory follow-up. In some circumstances a mandatory follow-up action is requested to ensure protection of the revenue potential on a CNC case including speciﬁc assets such as investment funds or full payment of an encumbrance of real property. Request mandatory follow-up only when required or when there is a likelihood that revenue will be collected by taking the requested action. Do not request a mandatory follow-up in the following instances: a. To update and review a CIS on the chance that a taxpayer’s ﬁnancial condition will change. b. If follow-up will occur in less than

days; these cases should be held the RO inventory. c. To check on future compliance with ﬁling requirements. d. To verify that payments are being made on an installment agreement. e. To verify that estimated tax payments are being made. f. To determine offset of a potential refund. g. To attempt to locate a taxpayer whose accounts were reported CNC closing code

) CCP will maintain a ﬁle for mandatory follow-up requests. These ﬁles will not be retired to the federal records center. CCP will: • File the cases by month and year of the requested action as determined by the originator. • File the cases alphabetically if a systemic monitoring program is used. • Generate and control subsequent actions with an ICS OI. Note: CCP will monitor in-business CNC cases for compliance. If the taxpayer incurs additional liabilities, an OI will be issued to resolve the liabilities.
